Dear Sir,

I have seen Dr. Brass and Mr. Rogers concerning Dr. Brass's account and am enclosing the account as amended according to your instructions. The two Cayuga boys were sent after I came to complete a course of treatment begun before the holiday. There is no charge appearing in the account for those former treatments.

The mastoid operation for Ralph Smart was an emergency operation. He has been directed by his doctor to go to the hospital. The Rogers' agent Department was notified by telegram and the following letter follows, but that no letter of explanation was received.

There was no additional fee paid or account from the agent before I met it in his neglected to do so.

This is to certify that,

Horace W. Smith

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

With further reference to Wilma Hill, 01059, I am enclosing report from Dr. Alexander, of the Brant Sanatorium. You will note that he states that she is not a fit subject to continue in residence in the Institute, and that she should be placed in a Preventorium. Pursuant to suggestion from Mr. Phelan, I have interviewed the authorities of the Brant Sanatorium and they will admit her to their Preventorium provided, of course, her admission is authorized by the Department with the assurance that the usual fee of $1.00 per diem charged to municipalities will be paid. I am, therefore asking for authority to place her in the Brant Sanatorium as this seems to be the only chance of her recovering her health.

PATHETIC END OF ANGLICAN RECTOR

COCHRANE, Ont., Aug. 10.—The Anglican rector at Moose Factory on James Bay, Rev. W. Haythornwaite, who was wounded severely, ended his suffering with a bullet.

On June 19th he committed suicide. Fortunately Rev. Walton was there at the time. Bishop Anderson who was at Albany was summoned and was making satisfactory arrangement to have the work of the schools continued. He has placed in charge Rev. Griffin from Albany until more satisfactory arrangement can be made.

It was discovered that several of the children in the boarding school were very badly affected with T.B. and gland trouble, so a weeding out was necessary in order to prevent the spread amongst the other pupils. Dr. Day examined every pupil and as a result some action had to be taken.

In the school there were five Neepineskum orphan children. Lizzie died last winter with T.B., and three of the other children Mary, Peter and Henry have developed the disease. These children are orphans and Bishop Anderson has agreed to place these children with the grandmother and to be looked after and properly rationed until such time as they are able to return to school, on condition that the Department continues to allow the usual grant to be paid the school for them.

Dey regarding their condition of health.

In reply I beg to say that the admission of these pupils for a term of three years is approved.

It is noted that Rev. J. T. Griffin has been placed, temporarily, in charge of the work at this school. When the new principal is secured I will be pleased if you would inform the Department as to the name, qualifications and experience which he possesses.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary
Right Rev. J. G. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moosonee,
Oochrane, Ont.

Mr. Maggrah is a Clergyman in good standing in the Church of England, and has resigned the Parish of St. Mary's, Brandon, Man., of which he was Rector, in order to accept this appointment. He speaks the Ojibwa language and has had considerable experience in Indian Residential School work, having been on the staff at the Shingwauk Home and subsequently on that at the Elkhorn School, before these institutions came under the administration of our Society. Mr. and Mrs. Maggrah will leave Mattice on the 17th instant en route to the Moose Fort School via the Mississipi River.

Trusting that this provision for the oversight of the Moose Fort School may meet with your approval.

I remain, Sir,

TORONTO, August 23rd, 1928.

Dear Mr. Perrier,

In this morning's issue of the Mail and Empire I find an article stating that Indian education costs have been re-arranged. May I know if this means any change with respect to the amount of cost which your Department will bear in connection with Indian education in Ontario. Or does the article refer to just the one situation which has been adjusted in keeping with general recent practice?

For a number of years a grant of £500.00 has been paid to the Bishop of Moosonee to assist in maintaining the Moose Fort and other schools in the James Bay district educating Indian children.

This is a matter that concerns the Provincial Department of Education. I believe that the Church of England officials have been in receipt of a grant from the Province towards the cost of educating children that were not wards of the Department of Indian Affairs. The usual practice is for the parents interested to form a school district and to ask the Provincial Department of Education for assistance, and, in the case of outlying districts like Moose Factory, to enlist the cooperation of a church or other interested organization.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dr. B. H. Hamilton,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory,
Ont.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 10th instant, 44-6-1, requesting information with regard to the Rev. Joseph Blackburn who is filling the position of Acting Principal of the Moose Factory School, I beg to state as follows:

Mr.

Field Secretary M.S.O.C.
Ottawa, February 18, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, relative to the appointment of Rev. Joseph Blackburn who is at present filling the position as acting principal of the Moose Fort Indian Residential School. The qualifications which Mr. Blackburn possesses have been noted. The Department will approve of his appointment, and it is hoped that under his management this school will meet with every success.

It will be sent to the Parkhill Trading Limited direct to cover the full amount, and, I hope, I shall be much obliged.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary

Reverend Sir:

The railway is apparently abandoning its past practice of operating a summer schedule - two trains per week - and is carrying through its past winter schedule of one train every second Wednesday.

A train is listed to leave Cochrane on Wednesday the 20th of July, returning from Moosonee on Friday July 22nd. Subsequent trains leave Moosonee August 5th and 19th. One or other of these latter dates will probably suit your proposed visit with Dr. Tyer to the Eastern Coast of the Bay.

I am having the Aladdin Construction Company working out the plans and cost of the proposed Preventorium and should the cost be within our present means, will write to you and Dr. Stone further in the near future.

Please accept this expression of my appreciation of your sympathetic interest in, and support of, our plans for placing a worthy and complete equipment at the historic post of Moose Fort, or Factory, whichever the correct title may be.

The person that came up from the Department could, if they could spare the time take the trip to Attawapiscat and Albany with me and get the train out on July 22nd.

I will have my mail sent on to Albany so if you let me know your decision I will make arrangements to pay Treaty to fit in with your plans.

Yours truly,

W.L.Tyler
Dr. W.L. Tyer
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory, Ont.
